name: Yuk Chuk Siu
description: The two ingredients needed to define the encoding of a set of symbols are 1) decide how many bits are we going to use in encoding  and 2) define a correspondence between symbols and binary encoding.Size of Encoding with 'n' bits ,  we have 2^n combinations and 2^n must be greater or equal to number of elements in a set.How to encode Characters?using the concept of catalog of correspondencenowadays computers use Unicode to encode charactersUAL-1consisting of 3 elements: code, operand 1 and operand 2.where code is divided into four possible values: ADD, SUB, MUL, DIVand operand 1 and 2 are divided into 256 possible values ranging from 0 to 255UAL-1 can also have 4*256*256 = 2^18 symbols meaning it will at least have 18 bits.Scheme: for a 24 bits encoding2 bits are for the 'Code'8 bits are for the 'Operand 1'8 bits are for the 'Operand 2'another 8 bits are zeros

name: Wing Kiu Ng
description: The video describes the method for encoding symbols. What determine this type of encoding include the number of bits and the corresponding symbols. The number of bits is related to the number of combinations. For example if there are 8 combinations, 3 bits are needed since 8 = 2^3. The bits are represented by the power of base 2.UAL- 1 is another way for encoding symbols. It is determined by three parts: the code, operand 1 and operand 2. The code consists of (ADD, SUB, MUL, DIV) while both operands can have any number between 0 and 255.

name: Brendan Allan March
description: This video describes how to encode a set of symbols.1) Choose no. of bits (n) to encode set symbols with, using the formula 2^n >= |Set|.2) Describe how the symbols are going to be encoded [ie: how to interpret the string of n bits].The video then gives an example of this process.

name: Luke Turner
description: This video describes how to encode sets of symbols in binary.This is achieved by following the two steps:1) Define how many bits are to be used2) Create a set of correspondence between the symbols and the binary encodingE.g., common protocols for character encoding are ASCII and UNICODE, using various amounts of bitsThe UAL -1 system was defined as having 24 bits, and includes certain rules, such as different binary codes for ADD,SUB,MUL and DIV, and that the two operands must be between 1 and 255.

name: Sheng Li
description: Encoding sets of symbols in binary requires the number of bits and the correspondence symbols in binary encoding.The size needs to be enough bits to cover all combinations within the setAlso a correspondence have to be introduced in order to encode your own sets of symbols

description: How to encode symbols in binary:1. choose how many bits you need to represent the set of symbols.2. choose a correspondence between each symbol and a binary string

name: Shing Him Ho
description: This video explained how computers generally encode symbols with the ual-1 encoding scheme as an example. There are two steps to do the encoding: Identify the bits needed to represent the symbol and find a binary correspondence.For example, in order to encode the 4 symbols (add,sub,mul,div)We can use 2 bits for the symbolsthen corresponding them with 4 combinations (00,01,10,11)

name: - Michael
description: Characters are made of Symbols and Binary and it uses 2^n set of combinations where n is the number of bits. 2 steps to encode set of symbols in binary:1.) Need to know how many bits you are going to use2.) Correspondence such as [CODE][OPERAND1][OPERAND2]. [CODE] = Letters, [OPERAND1] and [OPERAND2] = number of bits. Important thing to take note is to fill in the "Filler Bits"!!

name: Jisun Jang
description: The video explains how a computer systems encode symbols.The requirements to encode symbols are defining: how many bits are to be used, and the correspondence symbols.The number of bits are calculated using the formula 2^n >= |elements in a set|. The leftover bits are used as filler bits.The correspondence symbols are found by using UAL-1 scheme consisting of 'code', 'operand1' and 'operand2'.

name: Francisco Esteban Acosta Arroyo
description: In this video is shown the techniques that computers use to encode sets of symbols, and this is by following 2 steps:1. Choosing how many bits will be used when encoding:  This consists by making sure that the   number of bits is greater than the  number if elements on the set.2. Defining a Correspondence between Symbols and the Binary Encoding: This works by choosing a combination of  0s and 1s when they are single elements, or for characters there's types of encoding such as ASCII &amp; UNICODE.Another example is the example with UAL-1 shown that includes words with 3 elements (CODE, OPERAND 1, OPERAND 2) CODE: consists of Add, Sub, Mul, Div. It encodes 4 bits OPERAND 1: consists of any number from 0 to 255. It will encode 256 bits OPERAND 2: consists of any number from 0 to 255. It will encode 256 bitswhich at the end it will allow us encode at least 18 bits (2^18)e.g. ADD 53 28 == 000011010100011100000000with filler bits as it has been said that we will need bigger bits storing the set

name: Shanaye Appiah
description: - To encode a set of symbols you need two things:1. To choose how many bits to represent it in by calculating the total number of bits you need2. To define a correspondence table which sets out the symbols and their equivalent binary representation. Your correspondence also decides how many bits to allocate to each symbol- There are different types of encoding1. 8 bit ASCII which isn't able to represent as many symbols2. Unicode, which represents symbols for languages all over the world. It comes in 8, 16 and 21 bit variants (UTF)- You must transmit the decided number of bits, even if it is more than you get from encoding. The extra bits are filler bits- Usually longs strings are put into hexadecimal for simplicity

name: Madeline Frances Kim Pham
description: Techniques used to encode symbols:Two elements that must be considered when encoding symbols:1). How many bits (size)      n bits -> 2^n combinations      2^n >= the size of the set (number of elements)2). Corresponding symbols -> binary encodingexample 1:{Blue, Red, Green}use 2 bits (4>3)blue = 00, red = 01, green = 10, 11 (unused)example 2:Characters are encoded using a catalog (table with symbols on one side and code on the other)ASCII (8 bits) was originally used to encode charactersUNICODE (UTF-8, UTF-16 or UTF-32) replaced ASCII as it covers all symbols in all languagesexample 3: UAL-1{ADD=00, SUB=01, MUL=10, DIV=11}{OPERAND 1 ranges from 0 to 255 (next 8 bits)}{OPERAND 2 ranges from 0 to 255 (next 8 bits)}final 6 bits are filler bits (we arbitrarily chose the size to be 24 bits at the beginning)

name: Jimmy Photirath
description: Encoding Symbols Notes:1.	Decide how many bits to use to encode the symbol ( the size )-	n bits  2^n combinations-	we need to make sure 2^n >= the size of our set2.	Define a correspondence between symbols and the binary encodingExamples1.	{Blue, Red, Green}We will use 2 bits which give us 4 possible correspondences. -	Blue = 00-	Red = 01-	Green = 11-	10 is unused2.	UAL-1CODE | OPERAND 1 | OPERAND 2Code can add, sub, mul and divOperand 1 and 2 can have any number between 0 and 255.Number of elements: 4*256*256 = 2^18Therefore we can encode this set with at least 18 bits BUT let’s use 24 bitsCorrespondence:-	ADD: 00, SUB: 01, MUL : 10, DIV: 11-	Operand 1: 8 bits in base 2-	Operand 2: 8 bits in base 2-	6 bits all zero as ‘filler bits’Therefore: ADD 53 28 becomes 00 00110101 00011100 000000

name: Stephanie Wittnauer
description: ENCODING INFORMATIONGeneral points to consider:1. The total combination of bits needs to be >= the number of elements to encode (n).UAL-11. Three values to consider = code (add, sub, mul, div) + operand 1 (0-255) + operand 2 (0-255)2. Code represented by 2 bits, operands represented in 8 bits each and rest is padded with 0's (| total bits divisible by 8).

name: Cameron Little
description: •	N bits – 2^n combinationso	2^n >0 number of elements in the seto	e.g 0 2^2 = 4 which will wok for the three colours red, green, blue•	Ascii is 8 bits – 256 combinations•	UNICODEo	UTF – 8o	UTF – 16o	UTF – 32•	You need to ensure that the number of bits is greater than the number of elements that will be needed for that particular set. This is why it is so important to calculate how many bits will be needed.
